Having just been paroled, a legendary burglar played by Sam Jaffe with a perfect film noir criminal mastermind's name, Doc Riedenschneider, with funding from a tragic crooked lawyer, gathers a small assembly of career street crooks in the Midwest for a big jewel heist.

The film encompasses subject matter to which I am definitely partial, but it is particularly joyous for me to see because it was partially shot in my home town of Cincinnati, and there are particular shots in which I can tell that I am looking at a moving document of my city in 1950. There is even a point where I feel like I can comprehend what is just around the corner from what is being filmed.

Jaffe's Doc Riedenschneider becomes a very charming character, a German man with a great penchant for seeing right through people, as he organizes this job in a very professional and steady manner. Sterling Hayden, in his usual mediocrity, plays a hardened and unhappy thug from Kentucky with gambling trouble who sees the job as a way to bankroll his dream of buying back the horse farm that he lost in the Great Depression. A hunchbacked Italian diner owner is hired as the getaway driver, Anthony Caruso plays a professional safecracker and loyal family man, and Marc Lawrence plays a bookie functioning as the mediator.

In a taut 11-minute heist sequence, the criminals confidently carry out the heist in a patient and calm manner. Caruso climbs down into a manhole, pounds his way through a brick wall, climbs the basement stairs to the jewelry store, deactivates the door's alarm and lets in the other thieves, and then heads to the main safe. With care, he slides flat on his back under the electric-eye system, picks the gate's lock, drills holes into the safe's door, gingerly opens a corked bottle of nitroglycerin, and sets off a charge on the jewelry store safe. This is not all technical stuff, as the script is spiced up with some streetwise poetry, such as when they refer to the nitroglycerin as "the soup." And it takes talent to build upon a heist the way The Asphalt Jungle does. As the crooks do all of this, it seems well-planned just as Doc's arrangement of the operation is impressive, really a clever way of building his character. But, though I won't give anything away, we realize despite the thieves' mindsets of desperation and instinct after the heist goes down that these are not wise or reasonable men, or at least that is not the state of mind in which they have operated recently.

On the whole, this well-made, hard-boiled crime flick is quite good, and every male character is fashioned well through the actors, script and direction. The females, however, are not granted the same justice. Jean Hagen is a silly token weakling woman for the male character with whom she is coupled to boss her around. And thus my gripe with John Huston. The Asphalt Jungle, yes, is about hardened male criminals, and it is a male bonding picture, neither of which are bad, but there's a difference between a film like The Godfather in which the women "know their place" in the depicted traditional hierarchy and film like The Asphalt Jungle in which the only female characters---Marilyn Monroe's blonde squeaky bimbo who one could say ultimately screws things up for one character, Jean Hagen's lapdog of a blindly loyal and submissive quasi-girlfriend of Sterling Hayden's and Teresa Celli, an Italian housewife who only begins to take guff from another male character---are subjugated only because the filmmakers have decided for them to be.

There is great instant camaraderie between Sam Jaffe's ideological German mastermind and Sterling Hayden's compulsive Kentucky roughneck. Again, terrific depiction of male bonding, but couldn't there have at least been some depth to the female stick figures squeezed in just for the patronizing reason that the macho realm of the story seems a little dry and insulated without them? The reasons I am blaming Huston for this and not the writers are because I have not read W.R. Burnett's original novel and because Huston, as the director and co- screenwriter, he had every ability to flesh out these wasted women. Nonetheless, The Asphalt Jungle is a decent and entertaining noir that set the standards that Jules Dassin's Rififi would totally shatter only five years later.

A personal favourite. This is a film in which the focus of interest is in the flaws of the characters that come to roost. The film does not give in to the tough bravado that film noir sometimes indulged in. It is an acute examination of human failing, and that is ultimately what makes the tone so bittersweet. This is epitomised by Sam Jaffe being caught because he dallied too long to watch a pretty young girl dancing. He knows he would have escaped had he left when he first intended, but you sense that he senses he would have made the same mistake anyway - if not in that bar with that girl, then with another. Likewsie Louis Calhern. The scene in which he forgives his weak-willed mistress as she is confessing to the police is beautifully and delicately played. Of all John Huston films, this gets closest to his view of life. Life is a left-handed form of endeavour and this film shows why.

A newly formed crew pull off a million dollar jewel heist but when they are doubled crossed by their financial backer, all their careful planning falls apart. Similar to Double Indemnity in that what seems like a perfect plan unravels because of circumstances out of their control combined with weakness of character, The Asphalt Jungle is also the blueprint for the modern heist movie. Noir had evolved from the affected and literary roots of Huston's debut, and it resembles the contemporary crime film far more in its grittier style and more naturalistic characters and dialogue. Sterling Hayden is the pick of the cast of comparatively little known character actors, and the straightforward honour and dignity of a man who is assumed to be nothing more than a violent street thug contrasts both with the obsequious and double dealing face of respectability played by Louis Calhern and the corruption of the dirty cop who breaks the case. On the down side, the female characters are a little weak and the ending feels more anti-climactic than bleak and so I personally prefer the convoluted plotting and punchy firecracker dialogue of earlier Noirs, but for those used to more realism in their tough guy street dramas, this is a great starting point.

The Asphalt Jungle is about a major heist that goes wrong, and the reasons that it goes wrong are plentiful and ranging. This film makes many psychological and sociological observations as to the faults of the very foundations of crimes such as burglary and murder. One reason the heist is unsuccessful is that a stool pidgeon squealed to save his own hide, another is that a man gets greedy and tries to take all the jewels for himself. Heists and other crimes involving more than one person never work because the crimes themselves are based on selfishness, greed, and the compromising of morals. If that's your crime in the first place, then how can one ever trust who you're working with? If they were willing to commit one act for their own and undeserved good, what says that they wouldn't go even further against his partners in crime? This movie says, among other messages, that one cannot ever trust a crime partner or truly believe that they can get away with a crime. And Huston does not present this idea in a preachy way. He conveys these ideals in a fashion that makes complete sense. But quality messages like these aren't enough to make a great film, and The Asphalt Jungle stumbles in a few areas. Most importantly, no emotional weight is attached to anything in the movie. The main character, Dix, isn't a complete enough character to get the viewer engaged in the film. The viewer hardly gets to know anything about him, and this is also true about the rest of the characters. When there is hardly any emotional involvement with the characters in the movie, that makes it boring. The Asphalt Jungle heaps on the boring, not only because of the characters, but the plot is also conveyed in such a fashion that one would think that the director himself isn't very interested in his own story, either. It's nice to have a social statement, but it's even better if you present it in an environment with fully developed characters and a more interesting plot. The Asphalt Jungle is the first John Huston movie I've seen and given less than a 10/10, and I hope it's the last. I love Huston for his ability to complete involve the viewer in the story and take them on an emotional rollercoaster ride, but that important trademark seems to be sorely missing in this film. I hope that it's carried out through the majority of the films by John Huston that I still have to see.

[color=black]Asphalt Jungle. It's a 1950's Film Noir piece, and has all of the cliche's you'd expect. This is the story of a couple of joe's who are smalltime San Francisco hooligans. There is a crooked cop, a bookie, and a plan to take diamonds with the assistance of a recently released convict with a German accent, and lust for all women. Marilyn Monroe makes her big debut, by saying more than four lines in this movie. Sterling Hayden plays a big mook with a gambling problem. He owes big time. James Whitemore, who looks surprisingly like my ex-husband Dean, is a soda jerk and all around hoodlum. A codger is used as a front to cover diamond stealing expenses, then is going to be ripping the diamonds off of the bad guys. There are only bad guys. [/color][color=black]Every character has something crooked about him or her except for the long suffering bedridden gimpy wife of the guy fronting the cash. [/color]
[color=black]There is a full ensemble cast, and no one person stands out as the star. The direction is really the focus of this film. The story is a bit out there, with a lot of colloquialisms, and it is much longer than I expected it would be. The photography is stunning, with great long angles, rack focus play, and a lot of shadow work. Negative space is almost picasso-like..turning simple buildings into caves and walls. As a director's piece, it's brilliant. As a film for a story, it's not so great. The characters are hard to identify with, and that makes it a bit difficult to find a protagonist at all. The didactic pontification done by the police chief both at the beginning and in the end of the film is a bit over the top. Unlike Double Indemnity, one of my all time favorite films, I didn't feel attached to the story or the people portrayed. It was just motion wall paper. the one thing I did note, Marilyn Monroe's acting was just J-lo like... flat with sex appeal as the only purpose. I guess her presence always put her as a hero of mine, but her abilities as a thespian had a lot of holes. This movie made her a cartoon character out of hustler, and nothing more. [/color]

[color=#000000]Spartan is a film about some Secret Service agents keeping track of a presidential candidate or incumbant's daughter. There is never any mention of the actual job of the guarded family. In full Mamet fashion, the dialog is full of repeating lines, metered dialogue, and curious wordings. The way Mamet has decided to use the language of the world is completely unique. He colors pronouns, he dances around phrases, he calls back full conversations in three or four syllables. It's fascinating use of English.[/color]
[color=#000000]The story involves a kidnapped girl, who was under the supervision of the Secret Service. Val Kilmer plays a retired marine gunnery sargeant, who now works special programs, including the training of special recruits. It was hard not to see him as Batman in this. He played his character that way. It's not easy to figure out what the characters' realties are, but there is enough to keep you riveted and asking yourself, "okay, what now?" That kind of story is fascinating to watch. It was, at times, a little over my head. I readily admit that there were spots where I had no clue what was going on, and it would have been great to have Columbo or someone appear and fill me in. The kidnapping leads to sex slavery, and the people involved let the world think that the kidnapped gal was killed. It was all twists, and wildness. Bill Macy is a very creepy character. You're never really sure what he does, until the end, and I'll not be doing the spoiler thing.[/color]

rt_summary: Recently released from prison, Dix Handley (Sterling Hayden) concocts a plan to steal $1 million in jewels. Dix gathers a team of small-time crooks, including a safecracker (Anthony Caruso) and a lawyer (Louis Calhern), and the heist is a success until a stray bullet kills one of the men. As they scramble to pick up the pieces after the theft, the men let their greed get the best of them while entangling themselves in webs of deceit, treachery and murder.
meta_summary: A major heist goes off as planned, but then double crosses, bad luck and solid police work cause everything to unravel.
